name: Hverarönd
description:
Hverarönd is an alternative name often used to refer to the Námaskarð geothermal area near Lake Mývatn in North Iceland, though some sources distinguish it as a slightly separate section of the same geothermal field. This intensely active geothermal zone features dramatic landscape filled with bubbling mud pools, hissing steam vents, and sulfurous fumaroles that demonstrate the raw power beneath Iceland's volcanic surface. The ground is painted in vivid shades of yellow, orange, red, and brown from mineral deposits including sulfur, iron oxides, and other volcanic compounds. The area lies on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, where the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates are pulling apart.

The geothermal field at Hverarönd reaches temperatures exceeding 200°C just below the surface, creating an environment that is both beautiful and dangerous. Visitors can observe boiling mud pools that bubble and sputter continuously, sending droplets of grey mud several meters into the air. Steam vents release superheated steam with a constant hissing sound, while the pervasive smell of hydrogen sulfide fills the air. The landscape appears almost alien, with sparse vegetation and ground that has been altered by centuries of acidic geothermal fluids. Marked pathways ensure visitor safety, as straying from designated routes can be extremely dangerous due to thin ground crusts over boiling mud and water.

Located directly beside Route 1 (the Ring Road) approximately 5 kilometers east of Reykjahlíð, Hverarönd is one of Iceland's most accessible geothermal areas. A large parking area accommodates tour buses and private vehicles, making it a popular stop on the Diamond Circle route. The site can be explored in 20-40 minutes, depending on how thoroughly visitors want to photograph and examine the various geothermal features. The area is open year-round and free to visit, though winter conditions can make walkways slippery with ice. The geothermal activity is most visually dramatic in cold weather when steam plumes are more prominent. Nearby Bjarnarflag Geothermal Power Station demonstrates the harnessing of this natural energy.
opening_hours: Open 24/7 (parking available, stay on marked paths)
